body: Doesn't this break husks so they would require to use forcecapture?

that smells like allowing mapmodders to "sneak in" a option for trolling ... capture your allies buildings without them getting notified about this rule-change

beside that .. this is pretty controversy , as it allows (also as "obvious" option) your mates to be stupid ... therefor games could escalate more often

the idea of it -> #5691 should get more support or we should close it
Either enable by default in some mod, or don't do it.

> Doesn't this break husks so they would require to use forcecapture?

Fixed.

As I already mentioned this is nothing new, but already supported. https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/issues/5691#issuecomment-48113533

At the moment you will need

``` yaml
Rules:
    ^Building:
        -EngineerRepairable:
```

for it to work. This fixes it.
by supported i mean , "the idea of it getting obvious positive reactions" ... which isnt the case
the notification ... "This map contains custom rules." doesnt work 100%
Then file a bug report, please, so that this gets fixed.

still this doesnt look like it would close #5691 ... because xanax (and myself in the origin of the idea #5739 ) were looking for something to (atleast) turn on/off ingame 
something that extends the core-gameplay (worse enough now that im re-thinking it ) ... not just adding another map-modder option

but for a core-gameplay feature this would need more serious discussion ...
@pchote already rejected the lobby option variant. https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/issues/5691#issuecomment-51006790

okay you both have a point , then im indifferent on this

 (as im looking on this from a "player-perspective" not as a "modder" ... so , as long as the rules are protected and a notification pops up when they have changed , then i won't say anything against it ... i will open a ticket for the notification once i get the time for investigating it further )
I'd prefer if this would have a notation like what `Armament` got, by having a `TargetModifier` and a `ForceTargetModifier`. This way seems arbitrary atm.

> I'd prefer if this would have a notation like what Armament got, by having a TargetModifier and a ForceTargetModifier. This way seems arbitrary atm.

I agree (except for naming: `TargetStances` and `ForceTargetStances` like Armament would be better).  We can also set up infiltration/repair/etc the same way.

> the notification ... "This map contains custom rules." doesnt work 100%

I think this notification should have a clickable link to resource center, so people can easily see what the map changes.

@MustaphaTR : people want to "play games" ... and not every single player to study the rules before they decide to actually stay and play on a server ... "contains custom rules" is really easy and good enough ...

> > I'd prefer if this would have a notation like what Armament got, by having a TargetModifier and a ForceTargetModifier. This way seems arbitrary atm.
> 
> I agree (except for naming: `TargetStances` and `ForceTargetStances` like Armament would be better).  We can also set up infiltration/repair/etc the same way.

Updated as suggested.
Updated.

Could these be changed via including the force modifier passed an argument then checking for it explicitly?

:+1: otherwise.
I don't have access to the force modifier in those function, otherwise I would have mirrored the checks.
You can/should do what the attack code does, which gives you access to the force modifier in those functions.
I already checked. It is called in other contexts as well where those modifiers simply aren't available.
The two contexts I am aware of are the order targeting and ResolveOrder.  The modifiers are available in both.  What is missing?
The `CaptureActor` activity also uses it inside the `CanReserve` call which sounds like the denying context - although I'm not certain what that supposed to check for there.
That activity will be called via ResolveOrder, so there should be no problem.

However it might pay to try that in a separate commit - if the plumbing ends up being horrible then the current solution might be acceptable provided that we change Attack to use the same logic.  My main objection is to having inconsistent implementations, not to the current approach.

> That activity will be called via ResolveOrder, so there should be no problem.

Sorry, I can't find any `TargetModifier` near `ResolveOrder` in `Captures`.

While i'm no longer convinced that this is the right approach (see my last comment), my original comment on the topic said:

> You can/should do what the attack code does, which gives you access to the force modifier in those functions.

Please don't remove the changes requested tag until the discussion prompting it is resolved.  It was added in this case because of the inconsistency this introduces compared with AttackBase.  Making AttackBase do what you do here may end up being a better solution, but I can't definitively comment on that until I see working code.
Updated and experimented a bit. Exposing `TargetModifiers` into activities won't work and doesn't seem like something we want. I have no idea what to change in `AttackBase` nor how this is related.
So, what is the status here?
